results.content:
High level overview with simple project. Definitely not enough to jump into a real world application, but it is a great starting point, especially if you have some experience with MVC and need to quickly see few of the differences between Core 2.0 and MVC.
Instructor seems to know his stuff well, and explanation throughout the course, although not detailed (again, this is just an overview) is easy to follow and straight to the point.
Good job.

Really nice course to learn the basics of a web API. 

It covers every single aspect of web API: creating a RESTFul API, using swagger for specification, authorization with JWT and finally consuming the API from a simple web application.

Its a nice side course that goes along with other ASP.net Core courses.

After finishing the class, I will add the positives which I completely forgot in my first review.  The course covers the depth needed to get started building APIs very well.  I'm very happy to have been able to find such a thorough introduction covering asp.net core with entity framework and to have authentication/authorization explored from scratch.  I feel very much like I would be able to work and succeed as a backend engineer after this class!

results.content:
I wouldn't recommend this course. It's right on the edge of being 'good' but what pushes it down to 2 stars are:
- author ignoring important questions
- Storing the password in plain text (no salt/hashing)
- Worse no mention that the password should not be stored this way at all (amazing you didn't warn anyone).
- Missing content-type in Postman section which you need to make those calls work.
- Odd Class/Variable naming such as Upsert instead of Save, or SD in stead of something clearer (GlobalConstants).
- Wide open CORS setup again no mention as to why this is being done or that it shouldn't be left that way.
- Doesn't talk at all about Transcient versus Scoped, etc, I think a few minutes of some basics were needed there.
- Doesn't cover how to deploy this which is non-trivial and a pretty big deal because you're dealing with deploying the API and the Front-end and those have to be setup perfectly to work.

It's not all bad, I did like the style library stuff, the alerts, etc and the easy re-theming of bootstrap that I've never seen before. I also liked the use of generics for the repository and some of that stuff. The web-api section is pretty good an I liked that it didn't waste a ton of time, was pretty succinct.

Note: I've bumped my rating from 2.5 to 3 stars after reviewing the project structure, I actually quite like a lot of the basic design. It was actually easy to add salt/hashing since I had that already written. Overall I still think it's a little tricky to recommend this course if you are beginner, a lot of potential pitfalls, and the lack of instructor response to questions, etc.

results.content:
This course provides a very good overview of the dotnet API setup process. Sometimes I wished for a deeper explanation what dotnet does in the background of the framework and why it is important to use that line of code now (and what happens if you don't). But in general this course provides everything you need to get started with your own API project. I also liked that he used AutoMapper, that was missing in another course I've watched from him, so that added some additional value for me.

In general Bhrugen is a very good tutor in my opinion, but sometimes he rushes through some stuff and you have to go back and rewind a lot. In this course it happend more frequently than in "Complete guide to ASP.NET Core MVC (v3.1)" which I can really recommonend. Compared to the other course, this course is a bit flat, but as I said, you'll get everything to get started and I can still take away a lot from it.

results.content: It's a good course to cover the basics and some advanced features like authenticating an API and so on. For every subject there is a decent presentation. Nonetheless, many things are left unexplained and the course in general just touches the surface of the mechanisms of ASP.Net Core. The course would greatly benefit from more little API sub-projects, exercises, explanations and technical dive-ins so that a more concrete knowledge base will build up in the student. Nonetheless the course is good for a quick taste, just to sample how things are done in ASP.Net core.
